Links and Forms Toolset

Links and forms in Grimwire are used to control how requests are formed and how their responses are interpreted. Most of it will be familiar to Web developers, but many attributes are commonly used in Grim which are rarely used elsewhere, and some of the attributes are non-standard.


Target Links, Forms

Targets are used to specify where responses should populate the interface. Targets must specify the id of a valid client region. Alternatively, they can refer to one of the following special values:

  • _blank: a new browser tab
  • _top: the current browser tab (will navigate out of Grimwire)
  • _self: the current client region
  • _parent: not currently supported
Read more about targeting behavior in the Client Regions doc.

Type Links & Accept Forms

To specify the content type in the "Accept" header of the request, links should use the type attribute, and forms should use accept. If left unspecified, it defaults to "text/html". In links, this behavior is standard. Forms, however, deprecated accept with HTML5, and it was previously used to dictate uploadable file types. This should not cause any compatibility issues.

Grimwire chose accept for forms rather than type to avoid confusion with the standard enctype attribute, described below.

Enctype Forms

To specify the content type in the "Content-Type" header of the request, forms should use the enctype attribute. If left unspecified, it defaults to "application/x-www-form-urlencoded".


Form* Attributes Form Elements

Submitting elements (eg buttons) and fieldsets can override values in the form using formmethod, formaction, formtarget, formenctype, and formaccept. The form* attributes are used on a button when it is used to initiate the submit event. They are used on a fieldset when the fieldset is a parent of the submitting button.

Additionally, form elements can specify the form attribute with the id of a form which is not its parent. If specified, the given form's values (including the request payload) will be used instead of the parent.
